awd_titl_txt: Extensible Computational Services for Discovery of New Particles
awd_abstract_narration:
The origin of matter is one of the great puzzles of nature. Even though the visible component is only a small part of the mass/energy balance of the universe the strong force that permanently confines quarks and gluons to atomic nuclei remains mysterious. Understanding of the phenomenon of confinement is one of the fundamental questions in physics. Protons, neutrons and other hadrons are the bound states of quarks and gluons allowed by confinement. This project will pursue studies of individual hadrons and their interaction and is expected to offer a unique window into this fundamental phenomenon. In the process, this project will enable best practice spectroscopy analysis across a broad range of forthcoming experiments, particularly at the Jefferson Laboratory. Education activities are an integral part of this effort. Students will have ample training opportunities and will acquire computational and analytical skills that will serve them well in their future careers in the industry or academia. A vibrant set of summer undergraduate research experiences will be hosted by the investigators at the Jefferson Laboratory with both computer science and particle physics projects.

Developments in particle accelerators and detection techniques have led to a new generation of experiments in hadron physics that are flourishing around the world. An important set of experiments studies hadron spectroscopy,  what hadrons exist and with what properties. The new experiments at these facilities generate complicated data sets, which demand a qualitatively new level of sophistication in analysis never achieved before. The objective of the project is to develop new theoretical tools and underlying computational services for analysis of large statistics data sets from current and future experiments in hadron spectroscopy with the goal to search for new hadrons, in particular the so called, hybrids and glueballs, which are expected to carry some unique signatures of the confinement phenomenon. The unique features of the underlying theory of strong interactions also make it an attractive template for constructing theories beyond the Standard Model of fundamental interaction. This project will enable such work.

por.por_cntn:
Hadrons are bound states of quarks gluons, the fundamental building blocks of nuclear matter and determination of hadron spectrum is key to the understanding of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), the fundamental theory of strong interactions. The vast majority of hadrons can be classified as containing, either a valence quark-antiquark pair as it is in the case of mesons or three valence quarks in the case of baryons. A richer spectrum, however, is expected from QCD and several experiments, with more experiments planned for the future, have reported hadron candidates that do not fit the quark model classifications. In particular searching for hadrons with gluons as constituents, commonly referred to as hybrids, has been a high priority since gluons are responsible for quark confinement and mass generation and QCD dynamics cannot be fully understood without addressing the role of gluons in binding hadrons.

The key goal of this project was to develop novel theoretical and computational methods for analysis and interpretation of data from current and forthcoming experiments dedicated to hadron spectroscopy. Theoretical methods are based on the S-matrix principles and emphasize the analytical connection between different physical regions of crossing symmetric reactions. Computational methods take advantage of web-based services that contain a description of the reaction dynamics as well as a code repository for Monte Carlo generation and data analysis.  We make full use of the ideas of Regge theory and established the validity of Regge factorization over a large number of reactions by testing various assumptions about the Regge couplings and trajectories, e.g. SU(3) symmetry, exchange degeneracy. In particular, we established the role of a2 and rho exchanges at Jefferson Lab energies in great detail. We used these parameters in sophisticated finite energy sum rules that link high and low energy behavior of the amplitude. This provides critical constraints to the partial wave analyses used to discover new resonances.

The key to establishing the existence of hadron resonances is to understand their production mechanisms and decay characteristics. To this end, we construct reaction amplitudes based on their analytical properties, such as the location of poles and cuts. Discontinuities across cuts are constrained by S-matrix principles while the number and location of poles are determined by the underlying theory, QCD.  We use available QCD phenomenology, (e.g., quark models, lattice) and resonance-reggeon duality to hypothesize location of the poles, and when available, used the data discriminate between various resonance hypotheses. Besides gaining new insights into the observed production of hadron resonance, we made successful predictions for several recent merriments with the GlueX detector at the Jefferson Lab and made predictions for predictions for the forthcoming experiments at Jefferson Lab, CERN and Beijing Synchrotron. We have developed online tools for application of the reaction models to data analysis and simulations. A user can download source codes and complete them including standard simulation and packages such as ROOT or AmpTools (the later being developed with NSF support) used by practitioners in this field. The codes can also run online and display various physical observables produce sensitivity studies and produced uncertainty estimates. Through the duration of the project, the PI’s supervised several undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs who lead the individual project and though a collaboration-style publication policy, make contributions to multiple projects. We gave lectures at graduate schools on the topics of hadron spectroscopy, amplitude analysis, and QCD and participated in the organization of workshops and conferences.
